awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The GOGREEN Survey - Caring about the Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will use ground-based telescopes to study the vast population of "satellite" galaxies that live in the suburbs of cities of galaxies called clusters. We know that satellite galaxies can transform themselves from bluish systems rife with brilliant, young stars into reddish systems filled with dull, old stars. But models that attempt explain this remarkable transformation fail dismally. This means that the modellers need much more guidance about factors that govern a galaxy's life in the suburbs. The team will provide that important guidance. The team will also expand existing, successful outreach programs at their institutions. Areas of emphasis include high school students using the new data to conduct inquiry-based research, school teachers adding evidence-based research into their lesson plans, deaf students "smelling" and "touching" data that have been suitably transformed, and Hispanic students being encouraged to continue on from college to graduate school.

The aim of the project is to examine the physical processes responsible for quenching the star formation in clusters' satellite galaxies, as distinct from their central galaxies. Models of central-galaxy quenching agree well with observations. In contrast, models of satellite-galaxy quenching strongly violate observations, meaning that such models need better guidance about the processes involved. The team will provide that guidance by obtaining new spectroscopic data for massive groups and clusters at redshifts of 1-1.5 and comparing those data to existing lower-redshift data. These comparisons will be used to analyze the dominant modes of satellite quenching, how galaxies populate dark-matter halos as a function of environment, the relative timing of morphological transformation and star-formation quenching, and the dominant driver of size growth in quenched galaxies. These results will lead to new, better-informed models of satellite-galaxy quenching.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Funding from this award supported analysis of the Gemini Observations of Galaxies in Rich Early ENvironments (GOGREEN) Survey. This survey had two main components: 1) a 432 hour Gemini Observatory spectroscopic survey, and 2) a multi-passband photometric survey which totaled more than 100 hours on 4-8 meter class telescopes. The GOGREEN team found that galaxies in distant clusters and groups of galaxies are forming far fewer stars than galaxies in more typical environments, implying that dense cluster environments are more efficient at quenching galaxies.  The most important discovery which GOGREEN has made so far is that the dominant mode of environmental (satellite) quenching in the distant Universe is fundamentally different than in the local Universe. The GOGREEN survey also found that distant clusters and groups are active sites of galaxy transformation, that the efficiency of this transformation depends strongly on the total amount of mass in the cluster or group halo, and that quenching in GOGREEN systems is accompanied by a buildup of a passive disk population.  

As a result of this award, Wilson co-authored a total of 51 refereed publications including all ten GOGREEN manuscripts published to date. A major public release of GOGREEN data accompanied by extensive documentation was made in August of 2020. Catalogs and reduced data (images and spectroscopy) are available via the NSF's NOIRLab (https://datalab.noao.edu/gogreendr1/).  

Broader Impacts: The award enabled outreach activities impacting more than 50,000 people, two peer-reviewed pedagogical publications, 16 press releases, and the professional development of two UCR postdocs and five graduate students. Broader impacts activities included 50 K-12 workshops and public telescope viewings, an astrophotography competition, and two astronomy-themed interdisciplinary honors thesis projects (musical composition and theatrical play). Two projects were also developed to engage underrepresented minorities in STEM (hands-on astrophotography projects for her undergraduate breadth classes and "The Vibrating Universe", an astronomy workshop for deaf students). Details of both of these projects and assessment methods were published in peer-reviewed journals, and materials made publicly available.


Last Modified: 11/28/2021
Modified by: Gillian Wilson
